NewWords.WordPhrase: as far as ... is concerned 至于，就…来说
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The rise in interest rate will be disastrous in the case of small firms.

NewWords.WordPhrase: prevent from doing sth. 挡道；妨碍
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Many teachers complain that they can't make any improvement in teaching methods as the existing exam system is in the way.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  保卫者
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. he had to beat several defenders to score.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  the ruler of an empire 皇帝；君主
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. the Roman emperors

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  one's native country 祖国；家乡
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Many emigrants are planning to return to their homeland.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. causing great destruction 毁灭性的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Thousands of refugees are trapped by devastating war, draught and famine.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. cold and wet; not cooked, refined, processed, organized or analyzed 阴冷的；生的；未加工的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The events took place on a raw February morning.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  cold and miserable; depressing 寒冷刺骨的；凄凉的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The streets are deserted on a bleak winter morning.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. start; send (sth.) on its course 开始；发射
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Beginning in the early 1960s, humans launched probes to explore other planets.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. superior to all others 无比的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Though small, this restaurant offers a range of fish dishes unequaled anywhere else in London.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  a series of military operations or planned activities with a particular aim 战役；运动
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Some people complained that too much money had been spent on political campaigns.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the line dividing two countries or areas; the land near this line 边界（地区）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The terrorists escaped across the border.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  able to work well or producing a satisfactory result without wasting time or resources 效率高的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Remote terminals in the home, connected to data banks, make the home the most efficient place to work in many cases.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  conquering, defeat 征服，战胜
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Hitler badly miscalculated when he assumed the conquest of the USSR would be simple.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  producing a definite result or conclusion; having or showing the ability to decide quickly 决定性的；果断的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Most of the decisive land campaigns of World War I occurred on the continent of Europe.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi.  move back or withdraw when faced with danger or difficulty 退却   n.
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We adopted the following strategies: When the enemy advances, we retreat: when they retreat, we pursue.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. (cause to) become stuck and unable to make progress （使）陷入泥潭；阻碍  be/get bogged down be unable to make progress 陷入泥潭；不能前进
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Most of the tanks were bogged down because of mechanical defects and inexperienced crews.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v.  begin fighting with sb.; (cause to) take part in or do; occupy or attract sb.'s interest, etc. 与…交战；使从事；占用（时间、精力等）   engage (sb.) in sth. (cause to) take part in sth.（使）（某人）从事某事
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. They are currently engaged in lengthy trade negotiations.

NewWords.WordPhrase: have to deal with 面临；要对付
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The librarians were faced with the huge task of listing all the books.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  very important 至关重要的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Amazingly, our soccer team won the victory in the crucial final game.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  a thing one does with a risk of loss and a chance of profit 赌博   take a gamble take a risk 冒险
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The company took a gamble by cutting the price of their products, and it paid off.

NewWords.WordPhrase: continue doing sth. in a determined way （不顾困难）继续进行
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Our school authorities are keen to press on with educational reform.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. dusk 黄昏；傍晚
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. We hope to be back by nightfall.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the seizure and control of a country or areas; (one's) trade, profession, or business 占领；职业
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. During the Japanese occupation of China, millions of innocent Chinese people were killed by Japanese soldiers.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. an agreement to stop fighting 停战
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The fighting of recent days has given way to a truce between the two sides.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 沙皇
v.  (arch) wait （除下列习语外，已不通用） 等待  bide one's time wait patiently for a chance 等待时机
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. His political rivals are biding their time for an attack on his policies.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. hitting and then escaping 打了就跑的
prep. below zero; made less by 零下；减  a. negative; slightly lower than the mark stated 负的；减的；稍低的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Tomorrow's temperature will be as low as minus ten degrees centigrade.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a.  （温度）摄氏（的）
n. 大炮；火炮；机关炮
move slowly and with effort; continue endlessly and tediously 缓慢费力地走；拖延
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. These compensation cases have already dragged on for one year.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. grown bigger, wider, etc. than usual; expanded 涨水的；肿胀的；扩大的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The doctor says I've got swollen glands.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  一次；一回；一下；一击
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He won a car in the lottery last week. That's his first stroke of good luck.

NewWords.WordPhrase: with the loss of 以…代价
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The local government developed its economy but at the cost of environment.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. wearing torn and ragged clothes 衣衫褴褛的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. A tattered flag fluttered in the breeze.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vi. walk with difficulty, esp. when one foot or leg is hurt 一瘸一拐地走；跛行   n.
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I injured my ankle and had to limp.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. (cause to) become weak or weaker （使）虚弱；（使）变弱
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The Asian financial crisis severely weakened some countries.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 联盟
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. NATO is considered as the most powerful military alliance in modern history.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 落伍士兵；掉队者
v.  resign from being king, emperor, etc. 退位
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. When King George abdicated, his brother succeeded him on the throne.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the state of being sent away from one's native country or home, esp. for political reasons; forced absence 流放；流亡   vt.
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. He lived in exile for nearly six years.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 纳粹，国社党分子
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The Nazis were members of the right-wing National Socialist German Workers' Party, founded in Germany in 1919 and brought to power in 1933 under Adolf Hitler.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. an entering or being entered by an attacking military force 入侵；侵略
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. On Hitler's orders, the invasion of Poland began on September 1, 1939.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 帝国
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. the Roman Empire

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. formally announcing; a formal announcement 宣布；宣言
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The opening speeches sounded more like declarations of war than offerings of peace.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a concentrated military campaign intended to win a quick victory 闪电战
n. soft wet earth 烂泥
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The car got stuck in the mud.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. very quick or sudden 闪电式的，极快的   n. 闪电
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Police made a lightning raid on the house.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (usu. pl) a plan or method used to achieve sth. often against an opponent 战术
take sb. by surprise 乘某人不备
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The manager didn't know what to say. It was clear that my question had caught him off guard.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt.  give orders or directions to (sb.); teach (sb.) 指示，命令；讲授
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The family has instructed solicitors to sue Thomson for compensation.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. burn and destroy; cause to become dry and brown, esp. from the heat of the sun 烧光，使成焦土；烤焦
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. I scorched my dress with the iron.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt. cause (sb./sth.) to be in a specified condition 使成为
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Hundreds of people were rendered homeless by the earthquake.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. 德国人；德语   a. 德国（人）的
n. a person who is killed or injured in war or in an accident 伤亡人员；死伤者
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The precise number of casualties in yesterday's bomb explosion is not known.

NewWords.WordPhrase: have as the cause of death 死于
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Some animals died of starvation in the snow.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. a military operation in which an army tries to capture a town, etc. by surrounding it and stopping the supply of food, etc. to the people inside 围困
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The city was under siege for six months.

NewWords.WordPhrase: stop completely 使停止
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Air traffic in Poland had been brought to a halt by an air traffic controllers' strike.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. aggressive action, attack 进攻   a. used for or connected with attack; causing sb. to feel upset, or annoyed; very unpleasant 进攻的；冒犯的；使人不快的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The Red Army brought its winter offensive to a successful conclusion.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n.  attack made in response to an enemy's attack 反攻
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The army began its counterattack this morning.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. (pl) (a body of) soldiers 部队
because of 由于，因为
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Thanks to her financial support, the two children in the remote village could go to school.

NewWords.WordPhrase: a. having the characteristics of a hero; very brave 英雄的；英勇的
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The soldier saved the girl at the cost of his own life. His heroic deeds were appreciated by all the people in the community.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. area 地区
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. When examining a large geographic unit, geographers often divide it into smaller regions.

NewWords.WordPhrase: v. count; consider; think 计算；认为   be reckoned with be taken into consideration 被加以考虑
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. All these problems had to be reckoned with as they arose.

NewWords.WordPhrase: vt.  set too low an estimate on or for 低估
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. Never underestimate your opponent.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the quality of being severe; harshness 猛烈；严重
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The broken windows and doors of the house added to the severity of the winter.

NewWords.WordPhrase: n. the number of people or animals killed or injured in particular circumstances; money paid for the use of a bridge or road 伤亡人数；（道路、桥梁）通行费   take its/a toll cause damage, injuries or deaths 造成损失（伤亡等）
NewWords.Sentence: e.g. The famine took a toll of 3,000,000 lives.
